perturbation.original_text: The Breaching Party shall have sixty (60) days (thirty (30) days in the event of non-payment) after written notice thereof was provided to the Breaching Party by the non-breaching Party to remedy such default. Unless the Breaching Party has cured any such breach or default prior to the expiration of such sixty (60) day period (thirty (30) day period for non-payment), such termination shall become effective upon receipt of the written notice of termination by the Breaching Party to be given within ten (10) days of the end of such sixty (60) day period (thirty (30) day period for non-payment).
perturbation.changed_text: The Breaching Party shall have fifteen (15) days (five (5) days in the event of non-payment) after written notice thereof was provided to the Breaching Party by the non-breaching Party to remedy such default. Unless the Breaching Party has cured any such breach or default prior to the expiration of such fifteen (15) day period (five (5) day period for non-payment), such termination shall become effective upon receipt of the written notice of termination by the Breaching Party to be given within five (5) days of the end of such fifteen (15) day period (five (5) day period for non-payment).
perturbation.explanation: The original text provides a 60-day cure period for breaches and a 30-day cure period for non-payment. The modified text shortens these periods to 15 days and 5 days, respectively. This creates a legal contradiction because many jurisdictions require a longer cure period to allow the breaching party adequate time to remedy the default, especially in significant commercial agreements. A shorter period may be deemed unreasonable and unenforceable.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General contract law principles requiring reasonable cure periods; specific state laws (e.g., California) may imply a reasonable time for cure, which a court might find to be longer than 15 or 5 days depending on the nature of the breach.

perturbation.original_text: During the Term and for [***] ([***]) years thereafter, Aimmune shall keep, and shall cause its Affiliates and Sublicensees to keep and provide to Xencor, complete and accurate records pertaining to the sale or other disposition of Product in sufficient detail to permit Xencor to confirm the accuracy of payments due hereunder. Xencor shall have the right, upon [***] ([***]) days’ prior written notice to Aimmune, to cause an independent, certified international public accounting firm reasonably acceptable to Aimmune or reasonably acceptable to its Affiliates or Sublicensees, as applicable, to audit such records during Aimmune’s, or its Affiliate’s or Sublicensees’, as applicable, normal business hours to confirm the number of Product units sold, the gross sales and Net Sales of Product, the royalties payable, the method used to calculate the royalties payable, and the exchange rates used in accordance with Section 8.2. The audit shall be limited to pertinent records kept by Aimmune and its Affiliates and Sublicensees for any year ending not more than [***] ([***]) months prior to the date of the written notice.
perturbation.changed_text: During the Term and for one (1) year thereafter, Aimmune shall keep, and shall cause its Affiliates and Sublicensees to keep and provide to Xencor, complete and accurate records pertaining to the sale or other disposition of Product in sufficient detail to permit Xencor to confirm the accuracy of payments due hereunder. Xencor shall have the right, upon five (5) days’ prior written notice to Aimmune, to cause an independent, certified international public accounting firm reasonably acceptable to Aimmune or reasonably acceptable to its Affiliates or Sublicensees, as applicable, to audit such records during Aimmune’s, or its Affiliate’s or Sublicensees’, as applicable, normal business hours to confirm the number of Product units sold, the gross sales and Net Sales of Product, the royalties payable, the method used to calculate the royalties payable, and the exchange rates used in accordance with Section 8.2. The audit shall be limited to pertinent records kept by Aimmune and its Affiliates and Sublicensees for any year ending not more than three (3) months prior to the date of the written notice.
perturbation.explanation: The original text provides for a record-keeping period and audit notification timeline which is more standard in legal contracts, protecting both parties. The modified text reduces the record-keeping period to one year and the advance notice for audits to five days, while the audit should be limited to records for any year ending not more than three months prior to the date of the written notice. This is an unreasonably short period and could be deemed unenforceable or a breach of good faith, especially given the complexity of international sales and royalty calculations, and given that Xencor should have a certain level of ability to audit all the records to make sure their royalties are paid accurately.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General contract law principles of good faith and fair dealing; standards of reasonableness for audit rights.
